Graphical abstract A mesoporous carbon spheres assisted-Ru nanoclusters/RuO2 heterostructure catalyst modifies the adsorption energy of CO2 and induces the redistribution of charge density, thus boosting CO2 reduction significantly in a novel H2/CO2 fuel cell. Efficiently reducing carbon dioxide (CO2) into carbon chemicals and fuels is highly desirable due to the rapid growth of atmospheric CO2 concentration. In prior work, we described a unique H2/CO2 fuel cell driven by low-valued waste heat, which not only converts CO2 to methane (CH4) but also outputs electrical energy, yet the CO2 reduction rate needs to be urgently improved. Here, a novel Ru-RuO2 catalyst with heterostructure was grafted on mesoporous carbon spheres by in situ partially reducing RuO2 into ultrasmall Ru clusters (∼1 nm), in which heteroatom-doped carbon spheres as a matrix with excellent conductivity and abundant pores can not only easily confine the formation of Ru nanocluster but also are beneficial to the exposed active sites of Ru complex and the mass transport. Compared to pure RuO2 nanoparticles supported on carbon spheres, our composite catalyst boosts the CO2 conversion rate by more than 5-fold, reaching a value of 382.7 μmol gcat. -1h−1 at 170 ℃. Moreover, a decent output power density of 2.92 W m−2 was obtained from this H2/CO2 fuel cell using Ru-RuO2 embedded carbon spheres as a cathode catalyst. The Ru-RuO2 heterostructure can modify the adsorption energy of CO2 and induce the redistribution of charge density, thus boosting CO2 reduction significantly. This work not only offers an efficient catalyst for this novel H2/CO2 fuel cell but also presents a facile method to prepare Ru nanoclusters. Keywords CO2 methanation Fuel cell Generating electricity Ru nanocluster/RuO2 hybrid Ordered mesoporous carbon spheres 1 Introduction The rapid growth of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) concentration has become a major concern in most countries, which has resulted in severe ecological crises, such as global warming and glacier melting [1,2]. CO2 concentration in atmosphere emission from fossil-derived fuels has risen dramatically from 320 ppm in 1960 to above 410 ppm in 2019 [3,4]. To counter the increase of CO2 concentration, it is a favorable and prospective way to chemical convert CO2 into high value-added fuels by electrochemical, photochemical, and thermochemical approaches [5–8]. Among them, electrocatalytic CO2 reduction has attracted great interest due to its ease controllable of the process by electrode potential, simplicity, ambient reaction conditions as well as renewable electricity energy sources [3,9,10]. During CO2 electrolysis, excessive overpotential is required to drive CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) as the high thermodynamical stability of the CO double bonds (806 kJ/mol) [11] together with the sluggish reaction kinetics of CO2RR. Although sustainable green resources, such as solar and wind energy, can be used as input electrical energy, the intermittency of energy supply and storage challenges still hinder their practical participation in energy marketing [3,12]. Moreover, CO2RR can be accomplished via 2e-, 4e-, 6e- and 8e- processes [13], which also greatly rely on electrode potentials, thus resulting in diverse products [14–16]. Investigations on modulating the structures and compositions of catalysts have been extensively done to lower overpotential, and improve CO2RR efficiency and selectivity [17–20]. However, much more effort still needs to be made to achieve the practical applications of CO2RR. Is there another approach to reduce CO2 without relying on the external electricity? Some unique devices have been developed that are promising to achieve the possibility. Yasuo Izumi and his co-workers reported a polymer electrolyte fuel cell with 95 mol% methanol selectivity that uses platinum (Pt) as an anode catalyst to oxidize hydrogen (H2) and Zn-Cu-Ga as a cathode catalyst to reduce CO2. However, the current was not effectively measured [21]. In our previous work, an innovative H2/CO2 fuel cell was reported driven by waste heat energy [22]. This novel fuel cell can achieve CO2 methanation while also provide an alternative way of H2 storage by the formation of carbon-containing fuels, as well as alleviating energy crisis by generating electricity for human consumption. In particular, the battery stack can also be assembled to improve the electricity output based on advanced assembly technology of H2/O2 fuel cell. Moreover, the required heat energy, ranging from ca. 130 ℃ to 200 ℃, can be received effectively from low-temperature waste heat, which is typically wasted without recovery, resulting in severe energy waste [23]. Gibbs free energy of the total reaction is calculated to be −86.68 kJ at 170 ℃ [22], which indicates this CO2 conversion strategy can occur naturally. More specifically, CO2 methanation is a complicated 8e- transfer process, in which an efficient catalyst is highly desirable to boost the reaction. Pt/C is generally considered as a high activity catalyst in various catalyses. However, due to its outstanding performance toward hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), when Pt/C was employed as the cathode catalyst of H2/CO2 fuel cell, H2 was recorded as the major product rather than CH4 [24]. Ru-based catalysts are reported to show the optimal thermo-catalytic activity and high selectivity for CO2 methanation at a variable range of reaction temperatures [25–27]. In our previous work, RuO2 was demonstrated to be capable of CO2 conversion in this H2/CO2 fuel cell for the first time [22]. However, its conversion rate is not satisfactory, with a value of 66.25 μmol gcat. -1h−1 at 170 ℃. Recently, our group also found that Ru nanoparticles-embedded carbon nanofibers [28] and carbon nanotubes@hydrous RuO2 [29] can catalyze CO2 into CH4 in this H2/CO2 fuel cell with an improved conversion rate of 308.46 μmol gcat. -1h−1 at 170 ℃ and 331.2 μmol gcat. -1h−1 at 190 ℃ (108.9 μmol gcat. -1h−1 at 170 ℃), respectively. Thus, as a novel, attractive as well as challenging CO2RR strategy that is just beginning to develop, rational design and fabrication of a more efficient cathode catalyst is desirable to facilitate this research to continuously develop. The exposure of active sites is favorable to the enhancement of efficiency for an excellent catalyst. Preparation of ultrafine nanoparticles is feasible to expose as many as more active sites. Herein, N,O-codoped ordered mesoporous carbon spheres with a pore size of ∼12 nm and big specific surface area was first employed to confine the fabrication of ultra small Ru-RuO2 complex. A novel catalyst of Ru nanocluster-RuO2 finally was facilely grafted on mesoporous carbon spheres via an in situ chemical reduction method. This hybrid catalyst again demonstrates the possibility of CO2 methanation in this novel H2/CO2 fuel cell and also effectively improves CO2 methanation activity. Compared with pure RuO2 or Ru supported on carbon spheres, our Ru nanocluster/RuO2 heterostructure shows an improved conversion rate of 382.7 μmol gcat. -1h−1 toward CO2 methanation, which exceeds all catalysts we designed for this new system before. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that heterostructure of Ru nanocluster-RuO2 has a positive role in regulating the adsorption energy of CO2 and electron states of Ru-RuO2 catalyst, thus harvesting a high efficient CO2 reduction catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Ruthenium chloride hydrate (RuCl3·3H2O) was purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). Potassium borohydride and colloidal silica dispersion (Ludox HS-30, 30 wt%, suspension in water) were bought from Sigma-Aldrich. Aniline, ammonium persulfate, sodium hydroxide, sodium bicarbonate and phosphoric acid were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). Nafion (5 wt%) was bought from Shanghai Hephas Energy Corporation. Pt/C (HiSPEC 4000, 40 wt%) was supplied by Johnson Matthey (UK). Carbon paper (0.2 mm thick) was provided by Shanghai Hesen Electric Co., Ltd. Membrane made of polybenzimidazole (PBI, 80 μm in thickness) was obtained from Shanghai Shengjun Polymer Technologies Co., Ltd. Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) solution (60 wt%) was provided from Shanghai 3F New Materials Co., Ltd.. N2 gas (99.999%), H2 gas (99.999%) and CO2 gas (99.999%) were bought from Xi’an Taida Gas Company, Xi’an Weiguang Gas Co., Ltd., and Praxair (Shanghai), respectively. The reference CH4 gas was bought from Shanghai Weichuang Standard Gas Analytical Technology Co., Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts Polyaniline-derived mesoporous carbon spheres (PDMC) were prepared as the procedures in our previous work, containing polymerization, pyrolysis as well as the removal of SiO2 templates processes [30]. Partially reducing RuO2 into ultrasmall Ru nanoclusters (Ru NCs) with PDMC as carbon matrix (Ru-RuO2/PDMC) was synthesized as follows: 84 mg RuCl3·3H2O was dissolved into 50 mL distilled water by ultrasonic dispersion for 10 min. Then, 100 mg PDMC was directly added to the above solution under magnetic stirring, followed by an addition of 30 min’s of ultrasonication. Next, after the obtained mixture was continuously stirred for 4 h, 0.3 M NaHCO3 was dropwise added until the pH reached 7 ∼ 8. Whereafter, the as-received solution was slowly injected into 5 wt% KBH4 solutions under 80 ℃ reflux heating after vigorous stirring for one night. The mixture was then filtrated by vacuum suction to obtain the black powder. Finally, after being frozen and dried for one night, the powder was heated at 200 ℃ for 3 h at a heating temperature of 3 ℃/min under air atmosphere. Thus, Ru-RuO2/PDMC was obtained. RuO2/PDMC was prepared as the above except for the addition of KBH4. For the preparation of Ru/PDMC catalyst, NaHCO3 was not included and the heating process was eliminated. 2.3 Fuel cell assembly Both anode and cathode catalysts should be coated onto hydrophobic carbon paper. In a typical cathode electrode preparation, first, 20 mg Ru-based catalyst and 8 mg PTFE solution (30 wt%) were uniformly dispersed into excessive ethanol under ultrasonic dispersion for 30 min. Then, the obtained slurry was slightly coated onto the surface of the carbon paper. The cathode electrode was then received after heating at 60 ℃ for 4 h in an oven. The loading of the cathode catalyst is ∼ 2.2 mg cm−2. The anode ink was prepared in the same way as the cathode ink but with a little modification: 10 mg Pt/C catalyst and 10 mg 5 wt% Nafion solution were mixed into ethanol under ultrasonication for 30 min. The remaining steps are similar to those used in cathode fabrication. The Pt/C loading is ∼ 1 mg cm−2. PBI membrane was soaked into a H3PO4 solution for 48 h before assembly into a fuel cell. The anode, PBI membrane and cathode electrode were assembled into a membrane electrode assembly (MEA) with a sandwich structure using a heating press at 1.5 Mpa for 3 min (Fig. S1). The effective area of MEA is 4.5 cm2. Then, the obtained MEA was put into a stainless steel battery box and thus the fuel cell was assembled. 2.4 Performance test of the fuel cell The fuel cell was connected to a battery-testing system (Neware Technology Co., Ltd., Shenzhen, China) to evaluate the discharging performance of the MEA. The concentration of CH4 evolved from the cathode was determined by a gas chromatography instrument (GC 7980, Techcomp) with a flame ionization detector (FID, Plot U column), while the concentration of cathode H2 was detected by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD, Al2O3 column). Before each test, to avoid trace oxygen affecting the test, N2 needs to be introduced into both anode and cathode to remove the residual air until the open circuit voltage (OCV) was zero. Then, CO2 and H2 were supplied into cathode and anode respectively, with a CO2 flow rate of 9 sccm and H2 flow rate of 50 sccm controlled by a gas mass flow meter (Sevenstar D07-19B). TCD was also used to determine whether there is H2 leaked from the anode to the cathode under OCV state before each test (Fig. S2). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were conducted on an electrochemical workstation (CHI 660C, CH Instruments) from 0.01 Hz to 10 kHz at an amplitude of 5 mV. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of the cathode catalysts The structure of the H2/CO2 fuel cell is shown in Fig. 1 (a), in which MEA plays a key role. H2 is oxidized into two H+ and two electrons at the anode with Pt/C as an anodic catalyst, while CO2 is reduced into CH4 by the cathodic Ru-based catalyst, with H+ passing through proton conduction polybenzimidazole (PBI) membrane and electrons transferring via an external circuit. Thus, the directional movement of electrons generates electricity simultaneously achieving CO2 methanation. The reaction Eqs. (1)–(3) are as follows. (1) A n o d e : H 2 → 2 H + + 2 e - , E 0 = 0.000 V v s . S H E (2) C a t h o d e : C O 2 + 8 H + + 8 e - → C H 4 + 2 H 2 O , E 0 = 0.169 V v s . S H E (3) T o t a l r e a c t i o n : C O 2 + 4 H 2 = C H 4 + 2 H 2 O As presented in Fig. 1(b), the preparation of Ru-RuO2/PDMC is realized via firstly obtaining PDMC, containing polymerization of aniline precursor at ice bath, pyrolysis first at 300 ℃ and then at 900 ℃, leaching SiO2 templates at 100 ℃, and then deposition RuO2 nanoparticles onto PDMC, finally followed by partial reduction of RuO2/PDMC to obtain Ru-RuO2/PDMC. Fig. 2 (a) presents the XRD patterns for Ru/PDMC, RuO2/PDMC and Ru-RuO2/PDMC. XRD pattern for pristine PDMC exhibits in Fig. S3. A weak and broad peak at ca. 24 ° exists in all three Ru complexes, which was attributed to the (002) reflection of graphitized carbon from the PDMC matrix [30]. RuO2/PDMC only shows a weak and broad peak at around 35 °, which is ascribed to RuO2 (101) plane. A relatively broad peak at around 44 ° associated with the (101) reflection of Ru crystal can be observed in Ru/PDMC and Ru-RuO2/PDMC, indicating the presence of Ru in these two samples. Moreover, Ru-RuO2/PDMC also shows three other broad and weak peaks, reflected at 28 °, 35 °and 54.2 ° corresponding to the RuO2 planes of (110), (101) and (211) respectively. The coexisting of characteristic peaks of Ru and RuO2 in Ru-RuO2/PDMC demonstrates the successful preparation of Ru-RuO2/PDMC. The surface chemical composition and valence states of the as-prepared samples were investigated by XPS. The survey spectrum (Fig. 2b) indicates the existence of C, O, N and Ru elements in all these prepared samples. Specifically, the atomic contents of each element in the catalysts were presented in Fig. S4. The O percentage with a value of 19.81% in RuO2 is much higher than that of Ru-RuO2/PDMC (14.22%) and Ru/PDMC (10.65%), which is consistent with the fact that RuO2/PDMC has the highest O ratio. Ru/PDMC has the highest Ru content, reaching a value of 7.15%, while 6.49% and 5.75% of Ru species are measured in RuO2/PDMC and Ru-RuO2/PDMC, respectively. In addition, the content of N species is almost the same in the three samples, reflected at the range of 7.12%–7.39%. As shown in Fig. 2(c), the Ru 3p XPS spectra of Ru-RuO2/PDMC present two peaks corresponding to Ru 3p 1/2 and Ru 3p 3/2, which can be further deconvoluted into two doublets, respectively. The doublet peaks located at 486.8 eV and 464.5 eV are endorsed to Ru4+, whereas the other two at 484.6 eV and 462.3 eV belong to Ru0 [31]. The deconvolution XPS of Ru 3p directly demonstrates that Ru and RuO2 coexist in Ru-RuO2/PDMC. It is noteworthy that the binding energy of Ru4+ and Ru0 in Ru-RuO2/PDMC is positively shifted from those in RuO2/PDMC and Ru/PDMC respectively, showing that the decreased electronegativity of Ru atoms in Ru-RuO2/PDMC. The O 1s spectra for Ru-RuO2/PDMC (Fig. 2d) can be fitted into five distinctive peaks, where the peak at ca. 529.1 eV (O-1) is assigned to Ru-O-Ru and the band at 531 eV (O-2) can be ascribed to satellite peak and Ru-OH [32,33]. The other three peaks (O-3, O-4 and O-5) originated from the carbon network, corresponding to the carbonyl group, C-O ether groups and adsorbed water, respectively [33,34]. The position of the O-1 peak in Ru-RuO2/PDMC is negatively shifted from that in RuO2/PDMC, demonstrating the increased electronegativity of O atoms in Ru-RuO2/PDMC. To investigate the pore structure and specific surface area of the supported Ru-RuO2 onto the carbon matrix, N2 adsorption–desorption experiment was conducted, as shown in Fig. 2(e). Using the BET technique, all three samples show a type IV isotherm with a hysteresis loop in the P/Po range of 0.45–0.85, indicating numerous pores in the samples. The specific surface area of Ru-RuO2/PDMC (511.9 m2/g) is far lower than that of pristine PDMC (817.2 m2/g) [30], demonstrating that a number of Ru based nanoparticles formed in the pores of PDMC. In addition, the BET surface area of RuO2/PDMC and Ru/PDMC are only 441.4 and 345.8, respectively (Fig. S5a), indirectly showing that the much more nanoparticles of RuO2 and Ru formation in the pores of PDMC compared to Ru-RuO2 in PDMC. The pore volume with a pore width of 12 nm decreasing from ∼2.4 cm3 g−1 in PDMC to ∼1.7 cm3 g−1 in Ru-RuO2/PDMC (Fig. 2f) again confirms that the metal and metal oxides take up the pores of PDMC. The smallest pore volume of Ru/PDMC compared to the other samples indicates abundant Ru formation in the pores of PDMC. The detailed analysis of BET surface area in Fig. S5(b) exhibits that the samples include numerous micropores and mesopores, which are beneficial to the exposure of active sites and mass transport, respectively. The rich micropores and mesopores structure of the catalysts are further confirmed by pore volume analysis (Fig. 2g). The content of Ru or RuO2 was determined using thermogravimetric analysis (TG) in the air to determine the weight of the residual in the samples (Fig. 2h). Because the PDMC was lost in the form of CO2 during calcination, the Ru-RuO2/PDMC, RuO2/PDMC, and Ru/PDMC residues were 30.3 wt%, 34.9%, and 29.9%, respectively, which can be ascribed to Ru-RuO2, RuO2, and Ru. The morphologies and structures of the prepared samples are illuminated by FE-SEM, TEM and HRTEM images. Pure PDMC was chosen for comparison. Ultrasmall pores can be directly observed on the PDMC (Fig. S6). After Ru-based nanoparticles deposition, small bright spots can be found on the surface of the PDMC (Fig. 3 a and Fig. S7), showing that Ru complex has formed successfully. Fig. 3(b and c) clearly exhibits that Ru-RuO2 nanoparticles are well dispersed on the PDMC with a small size. The TEM image (Fig. 3d) further provides the exact size of Ru-RuO2, in the range of ca. 2–3 nm. The annular dark-field image of (101) diffraction ring (inset of Fig. 3e) indicates that the sizes of Ru particles are extraordinarily small, with a value of ∼1 nm (Fig. 3e), which demonstrates Ru nanoclusters (Ru NCs) formation in this Ru-RuO2/PDMC compound. Fig. 3(f) reveals the HRTEM of Ru-RuO2/PDMC, with a lattice spacing of 0.205 nm and 0.214 nm assigned to the (101) and (002) facets of Ru respectively, and a lattice spacing of 0.225 nm corresponding to (200) facet of RuO2. HRTEM image of Ru-RuO2/PDMC (Fig. S8) presents the structure at the heterojunction interface between Ru NCs and RuO2 nanoparticles. The mapping images of scanning transmission electron microscopy (Fig. 3h-k) demonstrate the uniform distribution of C, N and O elements throughout the whole selected area, while some Ru particles do not always appear with O element, indicating the existence of Ru simple substance. The above analysis confirms the successful preparation of Ru nanocluster-RuO2 compounds, which are uniformly dispersed on the carbon spheres. By contrast, TEM images of RuO2/PDMC (Fig. S9a and b) show that the size of RuO2 oxides in RuO2/PDMC is substantially larger when they are not partially reduced into the Ru cluster. Fig. S9(d and e) indicates that Ru particles in Ru/PDMC are quite small (1–2 nm) but still larger than that in Ru-RuO2/PDMC. Fringe spacing of the HRTEM images in Fig. S9(c and f) well corresponds to the facet of RuO2 and Ru respectively, confirming the formation of RuO2 in RuO2/PDMC and Ru in Ru/PDMC, respectively. 3.2 Cell performance for CO2RR The performance of different catalysts is then evaluated in a H2/CO2 fuel cell, as displayed in Fig. 4 (a-c). The performance increases with the enhancement of the reaction temperatures, reaching the highest power density at 170 ℃. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements (Fig. 4d) were used to reveal the reason for the enhancement. The bulk resistance is significantly lower at higher working temperatures, which should be attributed to the higher proton conductivity of the PBI membrane at higher temperatures [35,36]. Thus, much better cell performance can be received at higher temperatures. However, the bulk resistance shows a quite slow decrease when the working temperature rises from 140 ℃ to 170 ℃. This indicates that further enhancing the working temperature may not achieve better cell performance, which has been supported by the cell performance test at 190 ℃ (Fig. S10). The power density of 3.82 W m−2 with Ru/PDMC (Fig. 4c) as cathode catalyst is much higher than 2.92 W m−2 for Ru-RuO2/PDMC (Fig. 4a) and 2.46 W m−2 for RuO2/PDMC (Fig. 4b) catalyzed cells, which is not surprising that Ru metal has much better electron conductivity than RuO2 oxide. To compare CO2RR performance at different catalysts, the produced CH4 concentration in different cells at limiting currents was exhibited in Fig. 4(h). Remarkably, Ru-RuO2/PDMC catalyzed cell shows the highest CH4 concentration, which is much higher than that of RuO2/PDMC and Ru/PDMC catalyzed cells. Moreover, due to the excellent performance of Ru-RuO2/PDMC, it was further investigated at different discharging currents. Fig. 4(i) directly shows that the CH4 concentration increases as the discharging current enhances, from 44 ppm at 10 mA to 86.3 ppm at 32 mA with a CO2 flow rate of 9 sccm, demonstrating that CH4 generation rate increases with the discharging current. Thus, the electrons used to reduce CO2 into CH4 are originated from the electricity moving in the external circuit from the anode to the cathode electrode. The amounts of H2 detected at the cathode also increase as the discharging current enhances from 10 mA to 32 mA at 170 ℃ (Fig. S11), demonstrating that CH4 and H2 are both the products of this fuel cell. In addition, obvious droplets can be observed on the cathode surface after CO2RR, but not on the anode surface (Fig. S12), which is probably another product of H2O. The CH4 generation rate ( V CH 4 ) based on the three catalysts at different working temperatures was determined using the methods described in the Supporting Information. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), at each testing temperature, Ru-RuO2/PDMC all displays the fastest CO2 methanation rate, followed by Ru/PDMC, and RuO2/PDMC comes last. The CH4 generating rate of Ru-RuO2/PDMC is calculated to be 382.7 μmol gcat. -1h−1 at 170 ℃, which is far higher than that of Ru/PDMC (245.5 μmol gcat. -1h−1) and RuO2/PDMC (67.8 μmol gcat. -1h−1). Compared to the reported value in our previous work [22], the CH4 production rate of Ru-RuO2 supported on PDMC at 170 ℃ is almost 5.7 times that of RuO2 supported on carbon nanotubes (66.75 μmol gcat. -1h−1). As shown in Fig. 5(b), the CO2 methanation rate at different discharging currents was calculated to be 195.4 μmol gcat. -1h−1, 262.7 μmol gcat. -1h−1 and 382.7 μmol gcat. -1h−1 at 10 mA, 20 mA and 32 mA, respectively. This CO2 methanation rate is also superior to that of the values in the literature via photocatalysis (see details in Table S1), such as 51.8 μmol gcat –1h –1 by Ru/NaTaO3 [37],26.37 μmol gcat. –1h−1 by Ru/TiO2 [38] and 3.92 μmol gcat. –1h –1 by In2O3/g-C3N4 catalyst [39]. The CO2 transfer efficiency (CO2TE) was calculated based on the method in Supporting Information. As shown in Fig. S13, the CO2TE value of the Ru-RuO2/PDMC catalyst is 1.5% at 170 ℃, which is much higher than that of RuO2/PDMC and Ru/PDMC. It should be noted that the value of CO2TE can be greatly improved based on the cell stack structure as proved in our previous work [22]. Subsequently, the stability of the cell employing Ru-RuO2/PDMC as the cathode at 170 ℃ was evaluated by galvanostatic discharging at 50 A m−2. No obvious decrease can be observed during the test range of ca. 640 min (Fig. 5c), indicating the excellent stability of Ru-RuO2/PDMC toward CO2RR in this novel cell. Moreover, XPS analysis was conducted on Ru-RuO2/PDMC cathode before and after the stability test. As exhibited in Fig. 5(d), fluorine (F), oxygen (O) together phosphorus (P) elements are detected on the surface of the cathode, the first coming from the binder of Nafion solution and the latter two coming from H3PO4 of PBI membrane. The peak intensity of the high resolution XPS spectrums of Ru 3p decreases a lot due to the enriched phosphoric acid and Nafion binder on the surface of the cathode (Fig. 5e). The binding energy of Ru 3p 1/2 and Ru 3p 3/2 in the fresh cathode and the cathode after CO2RR show barely change, which confirms the excellent stability of Ru-RuO2/PDMC catalyst. In addition, the size of the catalyst almost remains unchanged after a relatively long-term CO2RR (Fig. 5f and g). HRTEM also confirms Ru NCs together with RuO2 nanoparticles can exist stably during this CO2 reduction process. The above results prove that Ru-RuO2 complex as CO2 reduction catalyst has excellent stability. 3.3 Analysis of catalytic mechanism for Ru-RuO2/PDMC To investigate how Ru and RuO2 cooperatively influence CO2RR activity, we then conducted First-principle calculations based on density functional theory (DFT). The Ru13 were modelled to represent the ultrafine Ru NCs in Ru-RuO2/PDMC. Ru38 was used to represent approximately Ru NCs in Ru/PDMC due to the much larger diameter of Ru NCs in Ru/PDMC than that of Ru-RuO2/PDMC. The model structure of Ru13 and Ru38 clusters were generated by the AB Cluster program [40]. Periodic slab models for the low energy-facet of RuO2 (110) surface [41] were constructed in a materials studio program using 2 × 2 surface supercells. The most stable structure of RuO2, Ru38 and Ru13-RuO2 (Fig. 6 a) were optimized within GGA-PBE function of PAW-PBE potentials via the VASP program. The optimal structures of CO2 adsorption on the above materials were also simulated (Fig. 6b). More details of DFT methods are described in the Supporting Information. The adsorption energies of CO2 on Ru-RuO2, RuO2 and Ru38 were calculated with Eqs. (4)–(6). (4) E 1 = E ( Ru 13 - RuO 2 )- CO 2 - E CO 2 - E Ru 13 - RuO 2 (5) E 2 = E RuO 2 - CO 2 - E CO 2 - E RuO 2 (6) E 3 = E Ru 38 - CO 2 - E CO 2 - E Ru 38 where the E ( Ru 13 - RuO 2 )- CO 2 , E RuO 2 - CO 2 and E Ru 38 - CO 2 are the total energies for the ground state of the optimized CO2 adsorption on Ru13-RuO2, RuO2 and Ru38, respectively. CO2 adsorption energy on RuO2 (E 2) and Ru38 (E 3) is −0.583 eV and −0.957 eV respectively, while in Ru cluster-RuO2 heterostructure, the CO2 adsorption energy (E 1) increases to −1.228 eV. These simulations reveal that the adsorption energy of CO2 on RuO2 is too weak to effectively adsorb CO2 molecule during CO2 reduction process. Although this value on Ru38 improves obviously, it is still unsatisfactory. In Ru13-RuO2 heterostructure, the adsorption energy of CO2 increases and improves the chemisorption CO2, which is beneficial for the adsorption of CO2 during CO2RR. Moreover, as exhibited in Table S2, CO bond distance of CO2 after adsorption on Ru13-RuO2 becomes longer, which is in favor of the subsequent break to generate methane. Although the CO bond length of CO2 absorbed on Ru38 or RuO2 also gets longer (Table S2), it is not as long as that adsorbed on Ru13-RuO2. The differential charge density of the Ru13-RuO2 heterogeneous interface is illustrated in Fig. 6(c), which shows that there is a redistribution of charge density around Ru atoms and O atoms in Ru13-RuO2. This indicates that electron exchange between the Ru and surrounding RuO2 exists. The total density of states (TDOS) of Ru13-RuO2, RuO2 and Ru38 (Fig. 6d) demonstrate that after partially reducing RuO2 into Ru nanocluster, the metal property of Ru-RuO2 composite is stronger than that of RuO2. The above DFT computations show that the Ru-RuO2 heterostructure catalyst can potentially improve the CO2RR activity. The above results can also be supported by the XPS analysis in Fig. 2(c and d), which confirm that there is electron interaction after partially reducing RuO2 into Ru clusters. Herein, we conclude the key points for the boosted catalytic activity of Ru complex (Fig. 6e). During the material preparation process, mesoporous carbon spheres confine the growth of Ru precursors in the small nanopores and thus the highly dispersed Ru nanoclusters were easily obtained. When the CO2RR occurs, the porous morphology of PDMC with a high specific surface area not only governs the good electronic conductivity but also increases the activity density of Ru complex for CO2RR. In situ partial reduction of RuO2 into Ru nanoclusters regulates electronic states, which optimizes the adsorption of chemical bonds and thus enhances the catalysis kinetics [42]. 4 Conclusions In summary, a highly efficient Ru nanocluster-RuO2 material with heterostructure grown on mesoporous carbon spheres was prepared and used as a cathode catalyst in a novel H2/CO2 fuel cell. The abundant mesoporous in the carbon matrix guarantee the uniform distribution of the Ru precursor and confine the growth of Ru and RuO2 in the pores. The catalyst of Ru nanocluster-RuO2 heterostructures, can achieve a high CO2 methanation rate of 382.7 μmol gcat. -1h−1 (5.6 times than that of pure RuO2), simultaneously generates electricity of 2.92 W m−2 at 170 ℃. It can be expected that the CO2 transfer efficiency and the outputs of electricity can be greatly improved based on the fuel cell stack structure as demonstrated in our previous work [22]. Based on DFT calculations and XPS analysis, the remarkably boosted performance could be attributed to the heterostructure of Ru-RuO2, which redistributes the charge density after partial reduction of RuO2 into Ru clusters and modifies the adsorption of CO2 onto the surface of Ru-RuO2/PDMC. This provides a favorable and feasible approach for the preparation of ultrafine Ru nanoclusters, and offers a prospective method to improve CO2RR performance in the future. coredata.dc:description: Efficiently reducing carbon dioxide (CO2) into carbon chemicals and fuels is highly desirable due to the rapid growth of atmospheric CO2 concentration. In prior work, we described a unique H2/CO2 fuel cell driven by low-valued waste heat, which not only converts CO2 to methane (CH4) but also outputs electrical energy, yet the CO2 reduction rate needs to be urgently improved. Here, a novel Ru-RuO2 catalyst with heterostructure was grafted on mesoporous carbon spheres by in situ partially reducing RuO2 into ultrasmall Ru clusters (∼1 nm), in which heteroatom-doped carbon spheres as a matrix with excellent conductivity and abundant pores can not only easily confine the formation of Ru nanocluster but also are beneficial to the exposed active sites of Ru complex and the mass transport. Compared to pure RuO2 nanoparticles supported on carbon spheres, our composite catalyst boosts the CO2 conversion rate by more than 5-fold, reaching a value of 382.7 μmol gcat. -1h−1 at 170 ℃. Moreover, a decent output power density of 2.92 W m−2 was obtained from this H2/CO2 fuel cell using Ru-RuO2 embedded carbon spheres as a cathode catalyst. The Ru-RuO2 heterostructure can modify the adsorption energy of CO2 and induce the redistribution of charge density, thus boosting CO2 reduction significantly. This work not only offers an efficient catalyst for this novel H2/CO2 fuel cell but also presents a facile method to prepare Ru nanoclusters.

coredata.dc:title: Ordered mesoporous carbon spheres assisted Ru nanoclusters/RuO2 with redistribution of charge density for efficient CO2 methanation in a novel H2/CO2 fuel cell
